newsitem.title: USA: Florida jobless rate edges up to 5.3 pct in Sept.
newsitem.headline: Florida jobless rate edges up to 5.3 pct in Sept.

text.p: Florida's unemployment rate edged up to 5.3 percent in September from 5.1 percent in August, the state Department of Labor and Employment Security said Tuesday.

That was down from 5.5 percent a year ago, and represents 372,000 unemployed Floridians out of a workforce of 7.02 million. The state's unemployment rate has been below the national rate for 15 of the last 19 months.
Florida added 161,300 jobs over the year, for a growth rate of 2.7 percent.
Services added the most jobs, 81,500, and had the fastest growth rate, 3.9 percent.
Trade gained 41,800 jobs for a 2.7 percent growth rate. Construction jobs continued to increase but remained well below the 1988-89 peak.
Manufacturing jobs declined by 2,000 over the year, with all of the decline in non-durable goods.

The transportation, communicatons and public utilities sector gained 7,000 jobs, for a 2.3 percent growth rate. Finance, insurance and real estate grew by 7,900 jobs or 2.1 percent, while government grew by 18,500 jobs or 2 percent over the year.
All of the state's metropolitan areas had over-the-year increases.
Tampa-St. Petersburg led with 28,800 new jobs, while Fort Lauderdale had the fastest growth rate, 3.4 percent.

Liberty County had the lowest unemployment rate, 2.1 percent, while Hendry County had the highest, 22.3 percent. Counties with the highest unemployment rates were in the agricultural areas of central and south Florida, where seasonal increases normally occur, the department said.
